message:
Step 1: Search for your laptop model online to find out if the keys come off
Step 2: On some laptop models, the keycaps can be gently pried off, giving you access to the surface beneath the keys
Step 3: However, the keycaps on some laptops are permanently attached
Step 4: Do an online search to determine if, and how, the keys can be removed.

The keyboard is a 20.3 x 7.8 cm matte black plastic case with a thin (2.6 mm) rubber dome membrane covering all of its keys.

## Parts

- [1x Keyboard](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B09WY5C6F4?th=1)
- [1x USB-C Cable](https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08P9RXYJH?th=1)

Note: if your keyboard has a different model number than the one specified in the first link above, please check the compatibility chart provided by the manufacturer.

Step 3: >

# Laptops without a dedicated laptop keyboard

Some laptops have no dedicated numpad keys (e.g. [https://www.dell.com/en-us/shop/dell-inspiron-15-5000-laptop/mz7m9n/4wv2t8/)|Dell Inspiron 5500] or (for example) use Fn+Num to switch between number and symbol layouts.

## Dell inspiron 15 3501

The following steps are specific for this model. However, it's likely that other models of the same series will also have similar layouts.

Step 4: >

If you have a laptop with a keyboard that is protected by an OEM password (e.g. Compaq Presario F700) you need to remove it before installing Linux or Windows on your computer.

The steps below will help you do this. This procedure has been tested successfully in 2006 on my Dell Inspiron 8600 with Compaq Presario F700 motherboard.

Note: If you have a laptop with a keyboard that is protected by an OEM password but it doesn't use a special BIOS password, see <a href="http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/linux-newbie-8/can-i-install

Step 1: Step 2: [EDIT] > This is a small fix for the "inst" command. It was used to insert instructions into the assembly code of the game and can be used as such again. The difference between these two commands are that the second one will not add an extra line to the log file, which is very important in some cases, as you do not want to see your own lines there. Step 3: Step 4: reword this instruction keeping all key details: "If you are using a Apple iPad or other device with an iOS operating system, tap the 'Settings' icon (located in the top right corner of your screen). Tap 'Wi-Fi'. Tap on the Wi-Fi network name and enter the password. Once you have connected to the network, click the refresh button (it looks like a circular arrow) to check if it is now listed as active."

This tutorial assumes you have already installed [http://www.libsdl.org/ SDL]. If not, please refer to the [[SDL installation instructions]].
If you want to play around with the Piston, click on here and press F5. The code for the example can be found in the piston-game/examples/test folder.

# How to use the POCO::Dynamic Library

## Prerequisites

This library is based on Boost, so you'll need to install it first:

1. Download boost 1.38 from [here](http://www.boost.org/users/download/), and extract the contents of the zip file into a folder named `boost_1_38_0`.

2. Create a new directory for your project (let's call it `test`).

3. Add the `test` directory as a source directory in the Visual Studio solution.

4. In your `test` solution, add a new project by right-clicking

Step 1: 





To build the `reform` library, install all required dependencies and run:

```bash
make build
```

and then install it in your project using either

```bash
make install
```

or by adding

```yaml
dependencies:
  reform: ^0.1.3
```

to your `pubspec.yaml`.

Step 4: ###[Inst] Install a new release of `gpg` and its dependencies
```
```sh

### 1. install dependencies
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade -y
sudo apt-get install libssl-dev libffi-dev build-essential python3-pip zlib1g-dev libbz2-dev

### 2. Install GPG
sudo pip3 install gpg --upgrade

### 3. Set up the keys
mkdir ~/bin && cd ~/bin
curl https://keybase.io/ghadi/key.asc | gpg --import
curl https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ghadi/
